Hello there! I work with sorbents in lab and particularly zeolite for almost 5 years, so here is my tips for using it and not breaking the sorbent layer : 1) you need to pour the sorbents onto filter only in wet state, so before pouring them, you should mix them with distilled water 2) before filtering, you should carefully add water to the column to maximum level, so nothing can break the sorbent layer 3) before filtration you should seal the top of the column to avoid the water from leaking and hit the side of the column with something, that is not gonna break the glass but is definitely hard (for example we used pens or pencils) until bubbles of air will stop coming. This way you will remove any excess air and ensure the proper filtration. We used to assemble dynamic filtration columns for radioactive strontium and caesium with zeolites and other sorbents this way. I am happy if I helped you in any way by this comment.

I know it's an old video, but Celite works much better if you pack it on a sintered glass funnel under reduced pressure, pour some solvent onto it, mix thoroughly so there are no clumps then apply vacuum to get rid of the solvent and it will form a nicely packed layer that won't be disturbed when you pour a liquid onto it.

another thing about that black water that was cause by the use of tap wter as a solvent:
the finer the particles of metals become, the blacker they get ... the same thing happens with salts (exceptions do apply of course). This also means that if you clean a metal surface with say abrasive milk and you notice black particles on your wipe, they aren't necessarily impurities/dirt, but just metal particles of the surcae that look now black.

I think thats cool. But this is exactly the problem with the chemical industry. Going so far away from natural processes, that you end up with a heap of just plain toxic and poison. Used in the food and cosmetic industry, this shit is leached in to nature and destroying the planet and us humans in the process. We should get back to using more 'natural chemistry' like alchemy was. Using and amplifying natures own processes and refining those things, which are natural and no shit becomes 'waste' that basically has no real use (only very specific ones) and is dangerous for the humans and the planet. It is fucking crazy how far this has continued, and is a god damn freak of nature. No real natural/useful/sustainable application, just trying to use poison to get another poison.

I'm not attacking this video, because this is good refinement of the 'Waste' into useful form (But how difficult!). But this video illustrates the problem perfectly... Take this process into more poisonous substances where the methods are more difficult and how these extracted unnatural chemicals are just being fucking spilled in to nature like is. Refining/extracting stuff to a poisonous chemical that you cannot get back from and can't be neutralized etc. And this is happening by the tons. We honestly as species need to take it back to the natural processes of nature or end up destroying the planet.

bunch

noun

They're a fine bunch of students.

Just treat it with sulfuric acid to about 2 pH, add some iron, raise the pH to 7 using Sodium Hydroxide, then add Sodium Hydrosulfide flakes at about 1-2.5% bv. Raise the pH to the desired precipitation pH for Mercury. Vacuum filter through a diatomaceous earth cake, preferably a cake which was deposited over a small rotary vacuum drum. The water may be discharged, and the cake may be disposed of as hazardous waste.

Great video, as always. I have suggestion for future synthesis - the Crystal violet dye, also known as gentian violet. It can be used for staining biological samples (like Eosin), it has some antibacterial effects and it can be used as pH indicator. In strongly acidic solutions, the color of the dye changes from violet to green and to yellow. In basic solutions, it decomposes and becomes colorless.
